question.title: Java SneakyThrow of exceptions, type erasure

node.contents: Can someone explain this code?

astNode.text: Can someone explain this code?

elements.contents: public class SneakyThrow { public static void sneakyThrow(Throwable ex) { SneakyThrow.<RuntimeException>sneakyThrowInner(ex); } private static <T extends Throwable> T sneakyThrowInner(Throwable ex) throws T { throw (T) ex; } public static void main(String[] args) { SneakyThrow.sneakyThrow(new Exception()); } }

units.rawText: public class SneakyThrow { public static void sneakyThrow(Throwable ex) { SneakyThrow<RuntimeException>sneakyThrowInner(ex); } private static <T extends Throwable> T sneakyThrowInner(Throwable ex) throws T { throw (T) ex; } public static void main(String[] args) { SneakyThrow.sneakyThrow(new Exception()); } }

node.contents: It may seems strange, but this doesn't produce a cast exception, and permits to throw a checked exception without having to declare it in the signature, or to wrap it in an unchecked exception.

astNode.text: It may seems strange, but this doesn't produce a cast exception, and permits to throw a checked exception without having to declare it in the signature, or to wrap it in an unchecked exception.

node.contents: Notice that neither sneakyThrow(...) or the main are declaring any checked exception, but the output is:

astNode.text: Notice that neither sneakyThrow(...) or the main are declaring any checked exception, but the output is:

elements.contents: Exception in thread "main" java.lang.Exception at com.xxx.SneakyThrow.main(SneakyThrow.java:20) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:57) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:601) at com.intellij.rt.execution.application.AppMain.main(AppMain.java:120)

units.rawText: Exception in thread "main" java.lang.Exception at com.xxx.SneakyThrow.main(SneakyThrow.java:20)at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:57)at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:601)at com.intellij.rt.execution.application.AppMain.main(AppMain.java:120)

node.contents: This hack is used in Lombok, with the annotation @SneakyThrow, which permits to throw checked exceptions without declaring them.

astNode.text: This hack is used in Lombok, with the annotation @SneakyThrow, which permits to throw checked exceptions without declaring them.

node.contents: I know it has something to do with type erasure, but i'm not sure to understand every part of the hack.

node.contents: Edit: I know that we can insert an Integer in a List<String> and that checked/unchecked exceptions distinction is a compile time feature.

astNode.text: Edit: I know that we can insert an Integer in a List<String> and that checked/unchecked exceptions distinction is a compile time feature.

node.contents: When casting from a non-generic type like List to a generic type like List<XXX> the compiler produces a warning. But it's less common to cast to a generic type directly like (T) ex in the above code.

astNode.text: When casting from a non-generic type like List to a generic type like List<XXX> the compiler produces a warning. But it's less common to cast to a generic type directly like (T) ex in the above code.

node.contents: If you want, the part that seems strange for me is that I understand that inside the JVM a List<Dog> and List<Cat> looks the same, but the above code seems to mean that finally we can also assign a value of type Cat to a variable of type Dog or something like that.

astNode.text: If you want, the part that seems strange for me is that I understand that inside the JVM a List<Dog> and List<Cat> looks the same, but the above code seems to mean that finally we can also assign a value of type Cat to a variable of type Dog or something like that.

node.contents: See my edit. Btw if I remember you come from the C# word so why do you advice not using stuff like Lombok's @SneakyThrow which helps to not deal with checked exceptions and do like in C#

node.contents: @SebastienLorber: Because when I'm writing Java, I try to write idiomatic Java. I don't see how SCJP certification is relevant in the slightest, by the way. Your edit talks about *assigning values* - where is a value ever assigned within your code?

node.contents: Sorry if it feels arrogant, just wanted to say that these stuff are subjects of the certification. I'll try to find a relevant code with an assignation to show you what I mean

node.contents: @SebastienLorber: In my experience, being certified doesn't mean that someone really *understands* the material at a deep level. In the course of interviewing *lots* of Java engineers, I can't say that I've seen any correlation between certification and understanding. Hence my view that it's not really relevant in your question.

node.contents: If you compile it with -Xlint you'll get a warning:

astNode.text: If you compile it with -Xlint you'll get a warning:

elements.contents: c:\Users\Jon\Test>javac -Xlint SneakyThrow.java SneakyThrow.java:9: warning: [unchecked] unchecked cast throw (T) ex; ^ required: T found: Throwable where T is a type-variable: T extends Throwable declared in method <T>sneakyThrowInner(Throwable) 1 warning

fragments.text: c:\Users\Jon\Test>javac -Xlint SneakyThrow.java SneakyThrow.java:9: warning: [unchecked] unchecked cast
^ required: T found: Throwable where T is a type-variable: T extends Throwable declared in method

units.rawText: c:\Users\Jon\Test>javac -Xlint SneakyThrow.java SneakyThrow.java:9: warning: [unchecked] unchecked cast throw (T) ex; ^ required: T found: Throwable where T is a type-variable: T extends Throwable declared in method .sneakyThrowInner(Throwable) 1 warning

node.contents: That's basically saying "This cast isn't really checked at execution time" (due to type erasure) - so the compiler reluctantly assumes you're doing the right thing, knowing that it won't actually be checked.

astNode.text: That's basically saying "This cast isn't really checked at execution time" (due to type erasure) - so the compiler reluctantly assumes you're doing the right thing, knowing that it won't actually be checked.

node.contents: Now it's only the compiler which cares about checked and unchecked exceptions - it's not part of the JVM at all. So once you've got past the compiler, you're home free.

astNode.text: Now it's only the compiler which cares about checked and unchecked exceptions - it's not part of the JVM at all. So once you've got past the compiler, you're home free.

node.contents: I'd strongly advise you to avoid doing this though.

astNode.text: I'd strongly advise you to avoid doing this though.

node.contents: In many cases there's a "real" check when you're using generics because something uses the desired type - but that's not always the case. For example:

astNode.text: In many cases there's a "real" check when you're using generics because something uses the desired type - but that's not always the case. For example:

elements.contents: List<String> strings = new ArrayList<String>(); List raw = strings; raw.add(new Object()); // Haha! I've put a non-String in a List<String>! Object x = strings.get(0); // This doesn't need a cast, so no exception...

node.contents: You have to think in terms of how the classes are structured. T extends Throwable and you are passing Exception to it. This is like assigning Dog to Animal not Dog to Cat.

astNode.text: You have to think in terms of how the classes are structured. T extends Throwable and you are passing Exception to it. This is like assigning Dog to Animal not Dog to Cat.

node.contents: The compiler has rules about which Throwable are checked and which are not, based on inheritance. These are applied at compile time and it is possible to confuse the compiler into allowing you to throw a check exception. At runtime this has no impact.

astNode.text: The compiler has rules about which Throwable are checked and which are not, based on inheritance. These are applied at compile time and it is possible to confuse the compiler into allowing you to throw a check exception. At runtime this has no impact.

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: Checked exceptions are a compile time feature (like generics)

astNode.text: Checked exceptions are a compile time feature (like generics)

node.contents: BTW Throwable is a checked exception as well. If you sub class it, it will be checked unless it is a sub-class of Error or RuntimeException.

astNode.text: BTW Throwable is a checked exception as well. If you sub class it, it will be checked unless it is a sub-class of Error or RuntimeException.

node.contents: Two other way to throw checked exceptions without the compiler being aware that you are doing this.

astNode.text: Two other way to throw checked exceptions without the compiler being aware that you are doing this.

node.contents: The only difference is that both use native code.

astNode.text: The only difference is that both use native code.
